prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band-3 12CO(1-0) low-z sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Our observing strategy consists on minimising overheads by using exactly the same tuning for a group of galaxies which have the CO(1-0)-115GHz line emission redshifted into the spectral windows which are set manually. Source redshifts are provided here:
HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.170 0.050840002 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.80 0.052359998 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.103 0.041010000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.55 0.053860001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.137 0.044090000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.235 0.026690001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.66 0.030590000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.26 0.18186000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.58 0.051870000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.45 0.050439999 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.23 0.033220001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.52 0.025380000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.42 0.054460000

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SAMPLE DESCRIPTION:
Restricted by the distance between sources in a single science goal, we had to remove one source presenting [CII] detection as it lies >10deg away from the rest, ending up with a sample of 27 galaxies for this ALMA proposal (see Fig.1 from science case).
We plan to observe the 12CO(1-0) and 13CO(1-0) emission at lowest resolution possible (~3.5" in Band-3) in all 27 sources, all of which are at different redshifts, from z = 0.025 up to 0.195. Given that the 13CO(1-0) line is 5GHz away from 12CO(1-0), we cannot observe both lines for one source in a single science goal. Our best solution was to fix the basebands by-hand in order to group sources that their redshifted CO line falls within the spectral coverage of the basebands, i.e. we minimise overheads by using the same tuning for sources within these groups. 3 tunings were required to cover the full sample. Note that source redshifts are set to zero given that the OT does not recognise these sources can be observed with the same tuning. Their redshifts can be found above on the science goal's description.
FLUX ESTIMATES:
To estimate line flux densities we consider (equations taken from Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005) Log(L_FIR) = 1.7 * Log(L'co)-5.0 (Figure 8) and L'co = 3.25*10^7 * Sco * Delta_nu * nu_obs^-2 * DL^2 * (1+z)^-3 (Eqn 3) and assume a line width of Delta_nu ~ 150 km/s.
The full optical extension of the sources is ~<20" (median 10" in diameter). We assume the 12CO(1-0) emission will be spread over half the optical area (an average of ~8 beams per source). In this way we estimate line 12CO(1-0) peak fluxes of the order of ~30mJy/beam on average for the population, with an estimated minimum value of ~2mJy/beam for the faintest source.
SENSITIVITY:
We aim to reach an rms=2mJy/beam in Band-3 @ 30km/s spectral resolution. At this depth, we expect to observe observe >~80% of the sources with a >3.5-sigma peak line detection. These detections are expected to increase by averaging channel widths but loosing kinematical information.
IMAGING:
The maximum recoverable area with no ACA is larger than the optical size of the galaxy (~<20"), therefore we estimate no issues related missing extended emission. Indeed, the 12CO area per spectral channel is expected to be even smaller. We request single pointing with no special requirements.
CORRELATOR SETUP:
We set the four basebands covering 1875MHz each. Within the spectral windows, basebands are touching eachother. Narrower spectral channels are not necessary for our science goals, so averaging 4 channels to get ~6km/s resolution is fine to reduce data rate.

Our observing strategy consists on minimising overheads by using exactly the same tuning for a group of galaxies which have the CO(1-0)-115GHz line emission redshifted into the spectral windows which are set manually. Source redshifts are provided here:

The maximum recoverable area with no ACA is larger than the optical size of the galaxy (~<20"), therefore we estimate no issues related missing extended emission. Indeed, the 12CO area per spectral channel is expected to be even smaller. We request single pointing with no special requirements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Our observing strategy consists on minimising overheads by using exactly the same tuning for a group of galaxies which have the 13CO(1-0)-110GHz line emission redshifted into the spectral windows which are set manually. Source redshifts are provided here:
HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.170 0.050840002 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.80 0.052359998 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.103 0.041010000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.55 0.053860001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.137 0.044090000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.235 0.026690001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.66 0.030590000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.38 0.058309998 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.26 0.18186000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.60 0.059370000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.58 0.051870000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.45 0.050439999 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.87 0.19499999 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.23 0.033220001 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.52 0.025380000 HOT2_EI_CII_G09.v2.42 0.054460000

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SAMPLE DESCRIPTION:
Restricted by the distance between sources in a single science goal, we had to remove one source presenting [CII] detection as it lies >10deg away from the rest, ending up with a sample of 27 galaxies for this ALMA proposal (see Fig.1 from science case).
We plan to observe the 12CO(1-0) and 13CO(1-0) emission at lowest resolution possible (~3.5" in Band-3) in all 27 sources, all of which are at different redshifts, from z = 0.025 up to 0.195. Given that the 13CO(1-0) line is 5GHz away from 12CO(1-0), we cannot observe both lines for one source in a single science goal. Our best solution was made to fix the basebands by-hand in order to group sources that their redshifted CO line falls within the spectral coverage of the basebands, i.e. we minimise overheads by using the same tuning for sources within these groups. 3 tunings were required to cover the full sample. Note that source redshifts are set to zero given that the OT does not recognise these sources can be observed with the same tuning. Their redshifts can be found above on the science goal's description.
FLUX ESTIMATES
To estimate line flux densities we consider (equations taken from Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005) Log(L_FIR) = 1.7 * Log(L'co)-5.0 (Figure 8) and L'co = 3.25*10^7 * Sco * Delta_nu * nu_obs^-2 * DL^2 * (1+z)^-3 (Eqn 3) and assume a line width of Delta_nu ~ 150 km/s.
The full optical extension of the sources is ~<20" (median 10" in diameter). The above equations are valid for 12CO(1-0), so here we assume the 13CO(1-0) emission will be spread over a sixth of the optical area (an average of ~3 beams per source), and that the flux density ratio is 12CO/13CO ~ 15 with the same line width of ~150km/s. In this way we estimate line 12CO(1-0) peak fluxes of the order of ~5mJy/beam on average for the population, with an estimated minimum value of ~1mJy/beam for the faintest source.
SENSITIVITY:
Given the limitations for observing this faint line, we only concentrate on its detection, not in its kinematical description. We aim to reach an rms=0.6mJy/beam in Band-3 @ 70km/s spectral resolution. At this depth, we expect to observe observe >~80% of the sources with a >3.5-sigma peak line detection. These detections are expected to increase by averaging channel widths.
IMAGING:
The maximum recoverable area with no ACA is larger than the optical diameter of the galaxy (~<20"), therefore we estimate no issues related to missing extended emission. Indeed, the 13CO area per spectral channel is expected to be even smaller. We request single pointing with no special requirements.
CORRELATOR SETUP:
We set the four basebands covering 1875MHz each. Within both spectral windows, basebands are touching eachother. Narrower spectral channels are not necessary for our science goals, so averaging 4 channels to get ~6km/s resolution is fine to reduce data rate.

We set the four basebands covering 1875MHz each. Within both spectral windows, basebands are touching eachother. Narrower spectral channels are not necessary for our science goals, so averaging 4 channels to get ~6km/s resolution is fine to reduce data rate.

SAMPLE DESCRIPTION:
Restricted by the distance between sources in a single science goal, we had to remove one source presenting [CII] detection as it lies >10deg away from the rest, ending up with a sample of 27 galaxies for this ALMA proposal (see Fig.1 from science case).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To understand how galaxies consume gas to form stars is a key goal of modern astrophysics. We constructed a sample of 27 galaxies selected from the Herschel-ATLAS survey presenting quality far-IR photometry, including PACS [CII]-158um spectroscopy. Our targets have L_FIR~10^(10.3-11.5)Lo, at 0.003<z<0.2, with optical sizes smaller than the field-of-view of ALMA. We propose Band-3 observations to detect 12CO(1-0) and 13CO(1-0) at 3.5" resolution. Imaging 12CO, aided by 13CO, provide a unique route to accurately measure the molecular gas mass (M_H2) available for star-formation. M_H2 will be used to put these galaxies in a global evolutionary context parametrised by the star-formation efficiency. The combination of [CII], 12CO and 13CO provide tight constraints on the global star-forming conditions: the density and far-UV radiation field. We expect to discover sources with anomalous line-to-continuum ratios which might evidence rare star-forming conditions. ALMA observations, coupled with the rich multi-wavelength coverage, make our proposal a powerful benchmark study of star-forming galaxies -- a key research for interpreting imminent [CII] detections in z>7 galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astrophysics, Pontifical Catholic University of Chile

Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine
Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Catolica of Chile, Pontifica University
